course.author: auth0|5b3a656445d8a648a1510a8b
course.title: Copy of St-Rémy Expert Brand Education
course.description:
Discover our 100% French Brandy:  St-Rémy !  This detailed course will help you better understand the French origins which makes St-Rémy so unique.

FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY

lessons.author: auth0|5b3a656445d8a648a1510a8b
lessons.title: A Short Quiz to Begin
lessons.description: Before we begin, complete the short Knowledge Check to test what you know about brandy, which is covered in the next chapter. Be sure to check the correct answer before you go to the next question.

items.title: Brandy is produced from what raw material?
items.feedback: While a brandy outside Europe can be produced from any fruit (plums, cherries, peaches, etc.), EU regulations state that a spirit label Brandy must be made with grapes.

items.title: Following EU requirements, what percentage of Brandy must be produced using grapes sourced in the European Union?
items.feedback: There are no rules regarding grapes origin in the EU regulation. However, St-Rémy decides to use 100% French grapes.

items.title: Following EU requirement, what is the minimum age that brandy must spend in an oak barrel with a capacity of less than 1000 liters before bottling?
items.feedback: The EU legal requirement for oak ageing with a capacity of less than 1000 liters for a  brandy is six months.

items.title: The P in VSOP stands for what?
items.feedback: The P stands for Pale in Very Superior Old Pale, which refers to the color of the brandy.  A VSOP brandy can hardly be overly dark without being colored with a regulated coloring.  Of course VS stands for Very Special and XO stands for Extra Old.

items.heading: Brandy Basics
items.paragraph: So as you can see, St-Rémy's commitment is to be 100% French even though EU regulations do not require it.  Let's learn more about brandy as product before we move on.

items.heading: Raw Materials
items.paragraph: Different spirits are made from different raw materials.  Please click through the flashcards below to see which spirit is produced from each raw material:

back.description: Whiskies are produced from cereal grains, like barley, wheat, corn and rye.  The grains are fermented into a low-alcohol beer and then distilled to reach the desired proof.
Rums are produced from sugar cane – either the fresh squeezed juice or from molasses, a by-product of the sugar-making process.  The molasses is fermented into wash and then distilled.
Tequila is produced from the agave plant, a member of the lily family.  The agaves are cooked, and the resulting sugars are then fermented before distillation.
While brandy can be made from almost any fruit worldwide, the greatest majority are made from grapes.  Grapes are harvested, pressed, fermented into wine and then distilled into brandy.

items.heading: Where does the term Brandy come from?

items.paragraph:
Brandy is an English word that refers to an eau-de-vie (distillate), usually made from grapes.

The word “brandy” originates from the old Dutch  brandewijn, meaning burnt wine.  Dutch traders, masters of the seas, developed the brandewijn business and made it famous around  all Europe. 

When England became a bigger player  in international trade, the word brandy did too.
Brandy can legally be produced anywhere in the world
France is considered to be the ancestral home of brandy, and its brandies are renowned for their quality

Note that Cognac and Armagnac are  "eaux-de-vie de vin" (wine spirit). In the EU there are 2 separated spirits categories : eaux-de-vie de vin and brandy. Besides, Cognac and Armagnac benefits from an AOC (controlled appellation of origin). AOC requirements includes limited area of production, regulated grape varietals, distillation and ageing process notably.

items.heading: St-Rémy Timeline
items.paragraph: Please scroll through the timeline below to discover some key dates in the history of St-Rémy:

items.title: Distillery Established
items.description: The distillery is established in Machecoul in the Loire Valley following the phylloxera outbreak which damaged the Charente vineyards, Paul-Emile Rémy Martin II selected Machecoul, where the Muscadet grapes were similar to “Folle Blanche", and set up a distillery to produce high-quality brandy.

items.title: Creation of "Fine St-Rémy"
items.description: The original 1917 recipe accounts for the essence of this unique and authentic French brandy.

items.title: Creation of the Unique St-Rémy Bottle
items.description: St-Rémy has always been a pioneer in the brandy world.  The St-Rémy bottle shape was been registered at the Commercial Court of Cognac in 1961.

items.title: St-Rémy is Exported to 80 Countries
items.description: St-Rémy begins to enjoy true international success

items.title: Martine Pain, St-Rémy Cellar Master, Creates St-Rémy XO
Martine Pain Creates St-Rémy Réserve Privée
items.description: This was the brand's first high-end limited edition

items.title: St-Rémy Small Batch Reserve is Launched with a Limited Release
Martine Pain Retires After 35 Years at St-Rémy
items.description: Cécile Roudaut takes the helm, after having brilliantly helped with the creation of limited editions of St-Rémy.

items.title: Inspired by its History and its Roots
items.description: St-Rémy, the world’s leading French brandy, updates its range’s packaging.  New look, same liquids!

items.title: Launch of Cask Finish Collection
items.description: Led by the expertise of Cécile Roudaut, a new release is made each year

items.heading: St-Rémy Roots Summary
items.paragraph: Review the key points from this chapter.
St-Rémy was founded by Paul-Emile Rémy Martin II, the fourth Rémy Martin, as a way to protect the family legacy during a time of crisis
St-Rémy has more than 134 years of authenticity and quality and is true global brand
St-Rémy has long been recognized for its innovation with limited edition brands

lessons.author: auth0|5b3a656445d8a648a1510a8b
lessons.title: St-Rémy Savoir Faire:  French Wines, Distilled in France

items.heading: St-Rémy is 100% French!
items.paragraph: One of the most important things to remember about St-Rémy is that it is 100% French from grapes to glass!  Our production is designed to protect the complex and diverse aromatics of the grapes.

items.heading: 100% French Grapes
items.paragraph: It all starts with selecting red and white wines from French vineyards:

items.heading: Heading
items.paragraph:
Round, subtle and well-balanced, St-Rémy’s character expresses the elegant diversity of the wine regions of France - the famous French terroir.

With all of France to choose from, the focus is first on the distinctive terroirs.

items.heading: Discover the Diversity of French Terroirs
items.paragraph:
Without the limitations of cognac - only made from a limited number of white grapes grown in a single region - St-Rémy has the luxury of choosing from diverse terroirs in France.  

Click through each of the four tabs below to see what makes each terroir unique:

items.title: Champagne* Region
items.description:
Sparkling wine region

Climate: Annual temperature of 50F (10 C)

Soils: Chalk

Grape varietals: Pinot Noir, Pinot Meunier, Chardonnay

Types of eaux-de-vie: Vegetable notes, smoothness on the palate, with power and fruit on the nose.


* The use is strictly regulated (wines with Contrôled Appellation of Origin), do not share externally

items.title: Bordeaux* Region
items.description:
Primarily red wine region, and also famous for dry and sweet wines from the Sauternes appellation

Climate: Oceanic temperate, without dry season, warm summer

Soils: Limestone and soil structure that is heavy in calcium. Areas of gravel, sandy stone, and clay 

Grape varietals : Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Semillon

Types of eaux-de-vie: Smooth, silky and velvety especially from the red varietals


* The use is strictly regulated (wines with Contrôled Appellation of Origin), do not share externally

items.title: Languedoc-Roussillon Region
items.description:
France's "wine lake" as it’s the largest region in terms of vineyard surface and production

Climate: Very dry in summer; the most arid and hottest region of France.

Soils: Soil varies from chalk, limestone and gravel based soils inland to more alluvial soils near the coast.

Grape varietals: Carignan, Shiraz, Grenache Red, Grenache White, Ugni Blanc

Types of eaux-de-vie: Light notes. They bring delicacy, refinement, purity, lightness.

items.title: Loire Valley Region
items.description:
Primarily white-wine region (dry, sweet or sparkling) 

Climate: Temperate and mild

Soils: Wide range of soils and subsoils present.

Grape varietals: Cabernet Franc, Gamay, Grolleau, Chenin, Sauvignon Blanc.

Types of eaux-de-vie: Delightful, fruity and floral notes, subtlety and sweetness.

items.title: CONTINUE
items.completeHint: Complete the content above before moving on.

items.paragraph: The diversity of grapes used in St-Rémy are a competitive advantage - they are specifically selected and distilled to provide specific aromatics.
Click through the images below to unearth the specific aromas sought from some common grape varietals used in St-Rémy:

back.description:
MERLOT

Regions: Bordeaux, Languedoc-Roussillon, South-West
Aromas: Blackcurrant, blueberry,  blackberry, prune, violet, coffee

GRENACHE

Regions: Languedoc-Roussillon, Provence, Rhone Valley
Aromas: Cherry, blackcurrant, prune, fig, licorice, chocolate, coffee, pepper

SYRAH

Regions: Languedoc-Roussillon, Provence, Rhone Valley
Aromas: Violets, blackcurrant, blackberry, spicy, pepper, liquorice, leather, game, truffle

CABERNET SAUVIGNON

Regions: Bordeaux, South-West, Languedoc-Roussillon, Provence
Aromas: Raspberry, blackcurrant, blueberry, green pepper, licorice, clove, smoke

CHARDONNAY

Regions: Burgundy, Jura, Champagne, Languedoc
Aromas: Apple, pear, lemon, pineapple, mango, cream, butter, bread, biscuits, almonds

SAUVIGNON BLANC

Regions: Bordeaux, Loire Valley,  Languedoc, South-West
Aromas: Boxwood, floral, gooseberry, grapefruit, lemon, peach, pineapple, lychee

items.heading: Heading
items.paragraph: This wide spectrum of aromatics gives the Master Blender a great palate to work with when crafting St-Rémy.

items.heading: Distillation
items.paragraph:
100% of our eaux-de-vie are distilled in France, most of the time in the region where the wines are produced.  Distilling them in France - close to the source- ensures the highest quality, and distillation is done to our exacting standards.

Then - and only when Cécile Roudaut deems it appropriate - a part of them are distilled a second time in continuous copper column stills.   If a spirit is judged to be too heavy on the nose or palate then a second distillation will give it more lightness, more purity and delicacy, allowing the fruity and floral notes to be more evident. 

Our style is based in elegant, complex eaux-de-vie with a lot of sweetness and above all no bitterness, the balance of which is managed by blending.

The graphic below provides an overview of distillation.  Click through the steps of distillation in order to better understand the process:

items.title: Wine Feed
items.description: The wine is fed into the still.

items.title: Winespirit Receiver
items.description: Distilled to no more than 82% ABV, the winespirit (eaux-de-vie) is collected into the receiver.

items.title: Condenser
items.description: Passing through a series of cooled water pipes, the vapors are gently condensed into liquid form.

items.title: Outflow
items.description: After the vapors rise through the Rectifier, they pass out through a pipe at the top.

items.title: Rectifier Column
items.description: This further distillation refines the product, increases the alcoholic strength of the eaux-de-vie.

items.title: Liquid Flows to Rectifier
items.description: After the initial distillation in the Stripping Column, the vapor flows into the Rectifier column.

items.title: Steam Rises
items.description: As the liquid interacts with the steam, the heat vaporizes the wine and forces the alcohol and other volatile molecules up the still. (Water and grain solids in the mash fall back to the bottom of the still).

items.title: Steam
items.description: Steam is pumped into the column.

items.title: Stripping Column
items.description: Heated wine is poured into the top of the column while steam is run through the hollow baffles; the steam and wine do not mix directly. The alcohol and other low boiling point liquids in the wine evaporate. The vapors rise while the low-alcoholic liquids fall.

items.heading: Heading
items.paragraph: At St-Rémy, distillation is focused on creating a balanced spirit and a pure taste.

items.heading: St-Rémy Grapes, Wine & Distillation Summary
items.paragraph: Review the key points from this chapter.
St-Rémy intentionally chooses a wide variety of French terroirs and French grapes to ensure a complex and diverse aromatic profile
Wines and distillates are produced only in France to ensure our exacting quality standards are met
Distillation is a specific process designed to ensure a balanced spirit with a pure taste

lessons.author: auth0|5b3a656445d8a648a1510a8b
lessons.title: St-Rémy Savoir Faire:  Blending, Maturation & Bottling in France

items.heading: Maturation
items.paragraph: St-Rémy eaux-de-vie matures in oak barrels and as time passes acquire their amber color, body & roundness, and their fruity & floral accents and light spicy notes.

items.caption: St-Rémy Ageing in Barrels
items.paragraph:
Ageing in oak casks is the way things have always been done at St-Rémy.  Small casks provide greater contact between the spirit and the wood.

  • A more intense spirit is created when there is greater exchange with the wood
  • Ageing in smaller barrels provides faster maturation while maintaining high quality
Quercus Robur has a wide grain, rich character and tannins and allows for more ageing potential. Fine grained oak provides sweetness and matures more rapidly. Click the image to expand it.
St-Rémy uses a medium long toast on their barrels, which provides a balance of caramel, vanilla and smoky/spicy notes.

Blending adds the final touch.

The Master Blender - Cécile Roudaut - looks after, selects, balances and measures out the wine eaux-de-vie, working her magic to blend and perpetuate St-Rémy’s signature style, flavors and smoothness.

100% Bottled in France!

After blending, St-Rémy is then bottled in the Loire Valley, and shipped around the world.

items.heading: St-Rémy Savoir-Faire Summary
items.paragraph: Review the key points from this chapter.

items.heading: St-Rémy Maturation & Blending Summary
items.paragraph: Review the key points from this chapter.
St-Rémy is matured in small barrels, made with Quercus Robur oak
The barrels are toasted medium-long and given a high heating to maximize vanilla sweetness
Blending is crucial and is the process in which our Master Blender perpetuates the St-Rémy house style

The St-Rémy product range can be separated into two groups:  the Core Range and Limited Editions.  Note that the Limited Editions are not available in all markets. 

Click each image to expand:

image.originalUrl: st remy CFC sherry duo 70 cl.jpg

items.paragraph: Scroll down to explore the current range in more detail:

St-Rémy VSOP embodies the iconic and historical taste of St-Rémy. It is a translation of the original recipe that made St-Rémy renowned around the Globe.

The right choice for a great authentic taste.

St-Rémy VSOP conveys the taste of small, freshly-picked red berries, while bringing out the sweet vanilla flavor of oak. It is a round, balanced spirit that is easy to drink.

With its light and subtle nose, St-Rémy VSOP is excellent neat, on ice or with a simple mixer.

items.heading: St-Rémy VSOP Tasting Notes
items.paragraph: When we show up to the present moment with all of our senses, we invite the world to fill us with joy. The pains of the past are behind us. The future has yet to unfold. But the now is full of beauty simply waiting for our attention.

Appearance:  Amber-yellow in color with golden glints.

Nose:  The alcohol notes are quickly replaced by rich fruity aromas of cherry, gooseberry and wild strawberry. Floral notes subtly blend with the woody and vanilla tones of oak. The overall impression is pleasing, harmonious and smooth.

Palate:  Round and smooth, fruits aromas and wood combine into an oaky vanilla finish.

items.heading: How to Drink St-Rémy VSOP
items.paragraph:
In a long drink glass, build on ice and top up with Cola, Ginger Beer, Ginger Ale or cloudy apple juice. Add a dash of fresh lime juice to zest it up!

During Winter, add St-Rémy VSOP in coffee or hot chocolate.

items.title: ST-RÉMY FRENCH COLA
items.description:
1.5 oz St-Rémy VSOP
3 oz Cola
2 dashes bitters
Orange slice

Into a tumbler full of ice cubes, pour St-Rémy VSOP and bitters. Top up with cola, garnish with the orange slice, stir with a bar spoon and serve.

items.title: ST-RÉMY FRENCH SANGRIA
items.description:
17 oz St-Rémy VSOP
40 oz ginger ale
17 oz Merlot wine
30 grape slices
10 orange slices
7 oz lime juice
10 oz red grape juice

Into a punch bowl, pour St-Rémy VSOP, red grape juice, Merlot wine, lime juice and ginger ale. Add grape slices and 1 cinnamon stick. Stir gently with a bar spoon for 15 seconds and serve.

Makes 10 servings

items.title: ST-RÉMY WHITE SANGRIA
items.description:
17 oz St-Rémy VSOP
40 oz ginger ale
17 oz Chardonnay wine
White grape slices
7 oz lime juice
10 oz white grape juice

In a carafe, combine St-Rémy VSOP, white grape juice, Chardonnay wine, lime juice and ginger ale. Add grape slices. Stir gently with a bar spoon for 15 seconds and serve.
Makes 10 servings.

items.title: ST-RÉMY FRENCH COFFEE
items.description:
1.25 oz St-Rémy VSOP
.50 oz vanilla syrup
1.25 oz whole milk
7 oz fresh coffee

In a large coffee cup, pour St-Rémy VSOP, the vanilla syrup, the whole milk then the hot coffee.

items.paragraph:
Global Brand Center

You can find all these cocktail videos, brand imagery and more on the Global Brand Center.

items.heading: St-Rémy XO - The Sophisticated Choice
items.paragraph: When we show up to the present moment with all of our senses, we invite the world to fill us with joy. The pains of the past are behind us. The future has yet to unfold. But the now is full of beauty simply waiting for our attention.

St-Rémy XO is the legacy of our previous Master Blender, Martine Pain. She created a rich and   complex brandy, her interpretation of French aromatic intensity, while remaining true to the style  of the House. 

The satisfaction of a generous superior taste for the savvy, bon vivant ones.

St-Rémy XO is a brandy of character with complex aromas and a robust taste. It is recognized for its elegance, roundness and ability to linger on the palate. Offering multiple layers of flavors that make it remarkable to critics and connoisseurs alike, St-Rémy XO can be savored neat, on ice or in classic cocktails.

items.heading: St-Rémy XO Tasting Notes
items.paragraph: When we show up to the present moment with all of our senses, we invite the world to fill us with joy. The pains of the past are behind us. The future has yet to unfold. But the now is full of beauty simply waiting for our attention.

Appearance:  Luminous amber color, tinted with subtle, rich red hues.

Nose:  Mature nose underpinned with delicate oak and vanilla aromas, layered with hints of ripe fruits and honey.

Palate:  Intense and aromatic. Subtle notes of wood and vanilla are enriched with flavors of gingerbread, candied apricots, dates, figs and nuts. The taste is subtly spicy and offers a long finish.

items.heading: How to Drink St-Rémy XO
items.paragraph: St-Rémy XO is very versatile, can be drunk in long drinks and classic cocktails!

items.title: ST-RÉMY APPLE & GINGER
items.description:
1.5 oz St-Rémy XO
1.5 oz ginger ale
1.5 oz apple juice
1 cinnamon stick
3/4 oz lime juice

Pour St-Rémy XO into a tumbler full of ice cubes and add apple juice, lime juice and ginger ale. Garnish with  1 cinnamon stick, stir for 6 seconds, and serve.

items.title: ST-RÉMY OLD FASHIONED
items.description:
2 oz St-Rémy XO
1 brown sugar cube
3 dashes bitters
Orange slice
Orange zest
Maraschino cherry

Into an Old Fashioned glass, put the sugar cube and bitters. Muddle it and pour in St-Rémy XO. Add ice cubes and stir with a bar spoon for 10 seconds. Press orange zest above the drink and garnish with an orange slice and maraschino cherry.

items.title: ST-RÉMY DAIQUIRI
items.description:
1.5 oz St-Rémy XO
3/4 oz lime juice
1/2 oz vanilla syrup
 Lime zest

Into a shaker, pour St-Rémy XO, lime juice and vanilla syrup. Shake for 10 second and double strain above a chilled martini glass.
 Garnish with lime zest.

items.title: ST-RÉMY BANANA BLISS
items.description:
1.25 oz St-Rémy XO
1/2 oz Crème de Banana

Pour St-Rémy XO and Crème de Banana into an old fashioned glass full of ice. Stir with a bar spoon for 10 seconds and serve.

items.title: ST-RÉMY THYME & AGAIN
items.description:
1.74 oz St-Rémy XO
4 drops peppermint tincture
3.5 oz Coca-Cola Signature Mixers Herbal
Smoke
Fresh thyme

Combine all the ingredients in a tumbler with ice.
Smoke the cocktail and thyme to fully experience the Herbal side of the drink.
Garnish with fresh thyme.

items.title: ST-RÉMY PAPER PLANE
items.description:
1 oz St-Rémy XO
1 oz Italian bitters
1 oz Amaro
1 oz lemon juice

In a shaker, combine St-Rémy XO, Italian bitters, amaro and lemon juice. Shake with ice and strain into a coupe glass.

items.title: ST-RÉMY ESPRESSO MARTINI
items.description:
1.75 oz St-Rémy XO
1 oz fresh espresso

3/4 oz coffee liqueur
1/2 oz sugar syrup

In a shaker, combine St-Rémy XO, fresh espresso, coffee liqueur and sugar syrup. Shake vigorously with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.

items.title: ST-RÉMY SIDECAR
items.description:
1.25 oz St-Rémy XO
1/2 oz Cointreau
1/2 oz fresh lemon juice
Orange zest

Into a shaker, pour St-Rémy XO, Cointreau and lemon juice. Shake it for 8 seconds and strain into a chilled martini glass. Press the orange zest above the glass and serve.

items.paragraph:
Global Brand Center

You can find all these cocktail videos, brand imagery and more on the Global Brand Center.

items.heading: St-Rémy is the N°1 French Brandy Worldwide
items.paragraph:
St-Rémy is the world’s favorite French brandy (IWSR data 2019),  prized by connoisseurs and critics alike since 1886.  

With 130 years of brand history,  the recipe continues to be passed down from generation to generation: It is a closely guarded secret known only to our dedicated Master Blenders.

items.heading: Below you will find a list of prized won by St-Rémy XO through years

items.title: CONTINUE
items.completeHint: Complete the content above before moving on.

items.heading: Cask Finish Collection
items.paragraph:
St-Rémy Cask Finish Collection is the top end expression of Cécile Roudaut’s expertise in selecting casks and in maturing carefully St-Rémy brandy in various types of wood.

Each release is a unique exploration, a unique encounter between our French grapes brandy and wood, a unique tasting experience.  Each release is rare and bottled in a very limited batch.

items.heading: The 2020 Release:  Oloroso Sherry Cask Finish
items.paragraph:
For this 5th expression, Cécile Roudaut’s quest for the perfect cask brought her to aging St-Rémy in 10 casks that previously held Oloroso Sherry from Jerez de la Frontera.

The result was above expectation, bringing to the brandy notes of red fruits, fresh butter, ginger and licorice.

Click through the images below to explore the region in Spain:

This expression “Finished in Oloroso Sherry Casks” includes a maturation stage in oak casks that previously held Oloroso Sherry, a fortified wine from the Jerez region of Spain.

The influence of Oloroso Sherry casks is identifiable as red fruit, cherries, figs, dates, citrus and raisins, cooked and candied fruits.

The oak of the cask plays a role, it delivers spicier notes of clove and dried fruits.

Cécile Roudaut says “The dance between brandy and sherry wood is like an expressive tango.

The Oloroso Sherry Casks create incredibly rich notes of red fruits, figs, dates, and cooked and candied fruits to St-Rémy brandy.”

Appearance:  Dark golden with amber hues.

Nose:  Red fruits, cooked and candied fruits   with a hint of biscuit.

Palate:  Round and sweet with notes of candied and dried fruits, biscuits, dates, chocolate and figs.

items.heading: St-Rémy Range Summary
items.paragraph: Review the key points from this chapter.
St-Rémy is very versatile and can be consumed in a variety of ways
St-Rémy VSOP & XO are award-winning brandies
The 2020 Cask Finish Collection is finished in Oloroso sherry casks with notes of red fruits, fresh butter, ginger and licorice

items.heading: The St-Rémy Target Client
items.paragraph: Men (& women), 30-45 years old, with medium household income.  Family and close friends as focal points; open minded and curious
Seek best value for money
Appreciate sincerity, integrity
Value traditions and brands with authentic roots
Feel satisfied if their family can live a good life they managed to build over years
Look for gratitude, simple gratification, understated  refinement and peace of mind by fostering comfort for themselves and the ones they care about
Confident in their choices and don’t look to prove anything.

items.heading: Heading
items.paragraph: Click through these images to discover more about St-Rémy's brand positioning:

items.heading: St-Rémy Brand Ambition
items.paragraph: Become the International Gold Standard for brandy

lessons.author: auth0|5b3a656445d8a648a1510a8b
lessons.title: Knowledge Check
lessons.description: Complete the Knowledge Check to successfully finish the course.  You must score 80% or higher to pass.

items.title: What year was the St-Rémy Distillery founded?
items.feedback: The distillery was founded in 1886 as disease ravaged the Rémy Martin vineyards.

items.title: Who founded the St-Rémy Distillery?
items.feedback: The distillery was founded by the fourth Rémy Martin, Paul Emile II.

items.title: St-Rémy is 100% what?
items.feedback: From grapes, to distillation, to maturation and bottling, St-Rémy is 100% French.

items.title: What brands make up the St-Rémy Core Range?
items.feedback: VSOP & XO are year-round brands in full distribution.

items.title: Who is the St-Rémy Master Blender?
items.feedback: Cecile Roudaut was named Master Blender in June 2016 following the retirement of Martine Pain

items.title: In 1961, St-Rémy moved to this iconic packaging
items.feedback: The black bottle has become strongly associated with St-Rémy

items.title: What is special about the grapes used for St-Rémy?
items.feedback: While St-Rémy is not required to use French grapes, they do so intentionally.

items.title: Why does St-Rémy choose grapes from a variety of terroirs & regions?

answers.title: To get the best white grapes since that is all that is used

items.feedback: The grapes used to produce St-Rémy are selected to provide a specific aromatic profile and are always from French wine regions

items.title: What type of still is used to distill St-Rémy?
items.feedback: Some eaux-de-vie are distilled a second time to ensure the proper aromatics & flavors are maintained.

items.title: What is special about the barrels used to age St-Rémy?
items.feedback: By using smaller barrels made from Quercus Robur oak, St-Rémy extracts the perfect balance of caramel, vanilla and smoky/spicy notes

items.title: What is special about the Quercus Robur oak used to age St-Rémy?

answers.title: Wood gives more sweetness and faster ageing
The wood does not burn quickly when toasted
Wide open grain that provides more maturation potential

items.feedback: Quercus Robur is ideal for long-term ageing

items.title: St-Rémy is described as the (blank) French brandy
items.feedback: Highly-awarded, St-Rémy is considered the most prestigious of French brandies

items.heading: Never Forget!
items.paragraph: St-Rémy is 100% French!

items.heading: Learn More
items.paragraph:
Visit the St-Rémy website to learn more about the history, production, limited editions and cocktail recipes!  

PLEASE DRINK RESPONSIBLY!
